statements.name: PROC CSPATIALREG
statements.description: The CSPATIALREG (spatial regression) procedure analyzes a class of spatial linear econometric models for cross-sectional data whose observations are spatially referenced or georeferenced. For example, housing price data that are collected from 48 continental states in the United States fall into the category of spatially referenced data. Compared to nonspatial regression models, spatial econometric models are capable of handling spatial interaction and spatial heterogeneity in a regression setting (Anselin 2001).

arguments.name: APPROXIMATION=
arguments.description: Specifies options that are related to approximating the Jacobian. You can specify one or more of the following approx-options: Chebyshev | TAYLOR specifies Taylor approximation. By default, Chebyshev approximation is used. NMC=number specifies a positive integer as the number of standard random normal draws for Monte Carlo simulation. By default, NMC=100. ORDER=number specifies a positive integer as the order of series in Taylor approximation or Chebyshev approximation. If Taylor approximation is used, by default ORDER=50. If Chebyshev approximation is used, by default ORDER=5. SEED=number specifies an integer seed.

arguments.name: CORRB
arguments.description: Prints the correlation matrix of the parameter estimates.

arguments.name: COVB
arguments.description: Prints the covariance matrix of the parameter estimates.

arguments.name: COVEST=
arguments.description: Specifies the method to calculate the covariance matrix of parameter estimates. By default, COVEST=HESSIAN.

arguments.name: OP
arguments.description: Specifies the covariance from the outer product matrix.

arguments.name: HESSIAN
arguments.description: Specifies the covariance from the inverse Hessian matrix.

arguments.name: QML
arguments.description: Specifies the covariance from the outer product and Hessian matrices (the quasi-maximum likelihood estimates).

arguments.name: DATA=
arguments.description: Specifies the primary SAS data set that contains dependent variables, and explanatory variables, and so on.

arguments.name: MAXFUNC=
arguments.description: Specifies the maximum number of function calls in the optimization process. The default is 1,000.

arguments.name: MAXITER=
arguments.description: Specifies the maximum number of iterations in the optimization process. The default value is 200.

arguments.name: MAXTIME=
arguments.description: Specifies an upper limit of r seconds of CPU time for the optimization process. The default value is the largest floating-point double representation of your computer. The time specified by this option is checked only once at the end of each iteration. Therefore, the actual running time can be much longer than r. The actual running time includes the remaining time needed to finish the iteration and the time needed to generate the output of the results.

arguments.name: METHOD=
arguments.description: Specifies the iterative minimization method to use. The default is METHOD=NEWRAP.
arguments.help: METHOD=CONGRA | DBLDOG | NONE | NEWRAP | NRRIDG | QUANEW | TRUREG

arguments.name: CONGRA
arguments.description: Specifies a conjugate-gradient method

arguments.name: DBLDOG
arguments.description: Specifies the double dogleg method

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Specifies that no optimization be performed beyond using the ordinary least squares method to compute the parameter estimates.

arguments.name: NEWRAP
arguments.description: Specifies the Newton-Raphson method (this is the default).

arguments.name: NRRIDG
arguments.description: Specifies the Newton-Raphson Ridge method.

arguments.name: QUANEW
arguments.description: Specifies the quasi-Newton method.

arguments.name: TRUREG
arguments.description: Specifies the trust region method.

arguments.name: NONORMALIZE
arguments.description: Suppresses the row standardization of the spatial weights matrix that is specified in the WMAT= option.

arguments.name: NOPRINT
arguments.description: Suppresses all printed output.

arguments.name: PRINTALL
arguments.description: Requests all printing options.

arguments.name: PRINTINTERNALNAMES
arguments.description: Prints internal names assigned to parameters.

arguments.name: PRINTTIMING
arguments.description: Prints a timing report.

arguments.name: WMAT=
arguments.description: Specifies the secondary spatial weights data set, which can be used to construct the spatial weights matrix W.

statements.name: BOUNDS
statements.description: The BOUNDS statement imposes simple boundary constraints on the parameter estimates. BOUNDS statement constraints refer to the parameters estimated by the QLIM procedure. Any number of BOUNDS statements can be specified. Each bound is composed of parameters and constants and inequality operators. Parameters associated with regressor variables are referred to by the names of the corresponding regressor variables: item operator item < operator item < operator item ...> > Each item is a constant, the name of a parameter, or a list of parameter names. Each operator is ’<’, ’>’, ’≤’, or ’≥’.

statements.name: BY
statements.description: A BY statement can be used in PROC CSPATIALREG to obtain separate analyses of observations in groups that are defined by the BY variables. When you use a BY statement, the primary input data set (specified in the DATA= option) should be sorted by the BY variables.

statements.name: CLASS
statements.description: The CLASS statement names the classification variables that are used to group (classify) data in the analysis. Classification variables can be either character or numeric.

arguments.name: DESCENDING
arguments.description: Reverses the sort order of the classification variable. If both the DESCENDING and ORDER= options are specified, PROC BCHOICE orders the categories according to the ORDER= option and then reverses that order.

arguments.name: MISSING
arguments.description: Treats missing values (., ._, .A, …, .Z for numeric variables and blanks for character variables) as valid values for the CLASS variable.

arguments.name: ORDER=
arguments.description: Specifies the sort order for the levels of classification variables. This ordering determines which parameters in the model correspond to each level in the data. By default, ORDER=FORMATTED. For ORDER=FORMATTED and ORDER=INTERNAL, the sort order is machine-dependent. When ORDER=FORMATTED is in effect for numeric variables for which you have supplied no explicit format, the levels are ordered by their internal values.

arguments.name: FORMATTED
arguments.description: Levels sorted by the external formatted value, except for numeric variables with no explicit format, which are sorted by their unformatted (internal) value.

arguments.name: FREQ
arguments.description: Levels sorted by the descending frequency count (levels that have more observations come ealier in the order).

arguments.name: INTERNAL
arguments.description: Levels sorted by the unformatted value. The sort order is machine-dependent.

arguments.name: PARAM=
arguments.description: Specifies the parameterization method for the classification variable or variables.
arguments.help: PARAM=EFFECT | GLM | ORDINAL | POLYNOMIAL | REFERENCE | ORTHEFFECT | ORTHORDINAL | ORTHPOLY | ORTHREF

arguments.name: EFFECT
arguments.description: Specifies effect coding.

arguments.name: GLM
arguments.description: Specifies less-than-full-rank, reference-cell coding; this option can be used only as a global option.

arguments.name: ORDINAL
arguments.description: Specifies the cumulative parameterization for an ordinal CLASS variable.

arguments.name: POLYNOMIAL
arguments.description: Specifies polynomial coding.

arguments.name: REFERENCE
arguments.description: Specifies reference-cell coding.

arguments.name: ORTHEFFECT
arguments.description: Orthogonalizes PARAM=EFFECT.

arguments.name: ORTHORDINAL
arguments.description: Orthogonalizes PARAM=ORDINAL.

arguments.name: ORTHPOLY
arguments.description: Orthogonalizes PARAM=POLYNOMIAL.

arguments.name: ORTHREF
arguments.description: Orthogonalizes PARAM=REFERENCE.

arguments.name: REFERENCE=
arguments.description: Specifies the reference level that is used when you specify a nonsingular parameterization.

arguments.name: 'level'
arguments.description: Specifies the level of the variable to use as the reference level. Specify the formatted value of the variable if a format is assigned. Replace <level> with an actual value.

arguments.name: FIRST
arguments.description: Designates the first ordered level as reference.

arguments.name: LAST
arguments.description: Designates the last ordered level as reference.

statements.name: DISPLAY
statements.description: The DISPLAY statement enables you to specify a list of display tables to display or exclude. This statement is similar to the ODS SELECT, ODS EXCLUDE, and ODS TRACE statements. However, the DISPLAY statement can improve performance when a large number of tables could be generated (such as in BY-group processing). The procedure processes the DISPLAY statement on a CAS server and thus sends only a subset of ODS tables to the SAS client. Because ODS statements are processed on a SAS client, all the display tables generated are first sent to the client and then the client creates a subset. If both DISPLAY and ODS statements are used together, the DISPLAY statement takes precedence over the ODS statements.

arguments.name: CASESENSITIVE
arguments.description: Performs a case-sensitive comparison of table names in the table-list to display table names when tables are subsetted for display. To preserve case, you must enclose table names in the table-list in quotation marks.

arguments.name: EXCLUDE
arguments.description: Displays all display tables except those specified in the table-list.

arguments.name: EXCLUDEALL
arguments.description: Suppresses display of all tables. This option takes precedence over the other options.

arguments.name: TRACE
arguments.description: Displays the display table names, labels, and paths.

statements.name: DISPLAYOUT
statements.description: The DISPLAYOUT statement enables you to create CAS output tables from your displayed output. This statement is similar to the ODS OUTPUT statement. The table-spec-list specifies a list of CAS output tables to create. Each entry in the list has either a key or a key=value format: key=value specifies key as the ODS table name, path, or partial pathname, and specifies value as the CAS output table name. key specifies key as the ODS table name and also as the CAS output table name. Table names and partial pathnames are discussed under the DISPLAY statement. The DISPLAYOUT statement does not support regular expressions.

arguments.name: INCLUDEALL
arguments.description: Creates output CAS tables for all display tables. The name of the created output CAS table is the same as the corresponding display table name. If you specify this option, the table-spec-list specification is ignored.

arguments.name: NOREPLACE
arguments.description: Does not replace an existing CAS output table of the same name.

arguments.name: REPEATED
arguments.description: Replicates the CAS output tables on all nodes.

statements.name: INIT
statements.description: The INIT statement is used to set initial values for parameters in the optimization. Each initvalue is written as a parameter or parameter list, followed by an optional equality operator (=), followed by a number: parameter <=> number

statements.name: MODEL
statements.description: The MODEL statement specifies the dependent-variable and independent covariates (regressors) for the regression model. If you specify no regressors, PROC CSPATIALREG fits a model that contains only an intercept. The dependent-variable is treated as a continuous variable in the primary input data set (specified in the DATA= option). Models in PROC CSPATIALREG do not allow missing values. If there are missing values, you get an error message.

arguments.name: CORRB
arguments.description: Prints the correlation matrix of the parameter estimates.

arguments.name: COVB
arguments.description: Prints the covariance matrix of the parameter estimates.

arguments.name: NOINT
arguments.description: Suppresses the intercept parameter.

arguments.name: NOPRINT
arguments.description: Suppresses all printed output.

arguments.name: PRINTALL
arguments.description: Requests all available output.

arguments.name: TYPE=
arguments.description: Specifies the type of model to be fitted. If you specify this option in both the MODEL statement and the PROC CSPATIALREG statement, the MODEL statement overrides the PROC CSPATIALREG statement.

arguments.name: LINEAR
arguments.description: Specifies the linear model.

arguments.name: SAR
arguments.description: Specifies the spatial autoregressive model.

arguments.name: SEM
arguments.description: Specifies the spatial error model.

statements.name: OUTPUT
statements.description: The OUTPUT statement creates a new SAS data set that includes variables created by the output-options. These variables include the estimates of xi'β, the expected value of the response variable, and the residual.

arguments.name: COPYVAR=
arguments.description: Adds SAS variables to the output data set.

arguments.name: OUT=
arguments.description: Names the output data set.

arguments.name: PRED=
arguments.description: Assigns a name to the variable that contains the predicted value of the response variable.

arguments.name: RESIDUAL=
arguments.description: Assigns a name to the variable that contains the residuals (that is, the difference between the observed and predicted values of the response variable).

arguments.name: XBETA=
arguments.description: Names the variable that contains estimates xi'β.

statements.name: RESTRICT
statements.description: The RESTRICT statement imposes linear restrictions on the parameter estimates. You can specify any number of RESTRICT statements. Each restriction is written as an expression, followed by an equality operator (=) or an inequality operator (<, >, ≤, ≥), followed by a second expression: expression operator expression The operator can be =, <, >, ≤ , or ≥.

statements.name: SPATIALEFFECTS
statements.description: The SPATIALEFFECTS statement enables you to specify covariates (such as X) whose spatial lag, WX, is to be added to the MODEL statement.

statements.name: SPATIALID
statements.description: For models that require a spatial weights matrix, the SPATIALID statement specifies a variable that identifies a spatial unit for each observation in the two data sets that are specified in the DATA= option and WMAT= option in the PROC CSPATIALREG statement. The variable that is specified in the SPATIALID statement is also used to match the rows and columns in the spatial weights matrix. Only one SPATIALID statement and one spatial ID variable are allowed. The values of the spatial ID variable in either the DATA= data set or the WMAT= data set cannot be missing.

statements.name: TEST
statements.description: The TEST statement performs Wald, Lagrange multiplier, and likelihood ratio tests of linear hypotheses about the parameters that are specified in the preceding MODEL statement.

arguments.name: ALL
arguments.description: Requests Wald, Lagrange multiplier, and likelihood ratio tests.

arguments.name: LM
arguments.description: Requests the Lagrange multiplier test.

arguments.name: LR
arguments.description: Requests the likelihood ratio test.

arguments.name: WALD
arguments.description: Requests the Wald test.
